Data files and knowledge base

Download knowledgebase.json

Note

Knowledge base is a combination of source files in data.

knowledgebase.json (first 200 lines)
  1{
  2  "What is DNA?": "The molecule that carries genetic instructions in living organisms.",
  3  "What is a gene?": "A gene is a segment of DNA that contains the instructions to produce proteins, which perform essential functions in the body.",
  4  "What is a chromosome?": "Chromosomes are long DNA molecules wrapped around proteins, containing many genes. Humans typically have 23 pairs (= 46 chromosomes).",
  5  "What is an allele?": "An allele is a variant form of a gene at a specific locus. Different alleles can influence traits in various ways.",
  6  "What is genotype?": "Genotype refers to an individual's genetic makeup, representing the combination of alleles inherited from both parents.",
  7  "What is phenotype?": "Phenotype is the observable traits of an individual, shaped by genotype and environmental factors.",
  8  "What is Y-DNA?": "Y-DNA is the paternal lineage DNA passed from father to son. It is used to trace paternal ancestry through haplogroups.",
  9  "What is mtDNA?": "Mitochondrial DNA inherited from the mother.",
 10  "What is a SNP?": "A Single Nucleotide Polymorphism (SNP) is a variation at a single position in the DNA sequence among individuals.",
 11  "What is an STR?": "Short Tandem Repeats (STRs) are repeating sequences in DNA that vary in length and are used in genetic genealogy for matching relatives.",
 12  "What are haplogroup subclades?": "Subclades are branches within a haplogroup representing more recent common ancestors.",
 13  "Why do people test BigY-700?": "BigY-700 analyzes hundreds of thousands of Y-DNA markers to identify deep paternal ancestry and refine haplogroup placement.",
 14  "What is a genetic genealogy test?": "A genetic genealogy test analyzes your DNA to discover ancestry, relatives, and historical migrations.",
 15  "What is autosomal DNA?": "Autosomal DNA is inherited from both parents and can reveal relatives from all ancestral lines within about 5-6 generations.",
 16  "What is a haplotype?": "A combination of DNA variations inherited together.",
 17  "What is STR matching?": "STR matching compares short tandem repeats to find genetic relatives on the paternal or maternal lines.",
 18  "What is STR testing?": "STR testing analyzes short tandem repeats to compare genetic similarity and recent ancestry.",
 19  "What is SNP testing?": "SNP testing identifies single nucleotide variations that help determine haplogroup and fine-scale ancestry.",
 20  "What is a private SNP?": "A private SNP is a mutation found in a single lineage or family branch, indicating recent ancestry.",
 21  "How do haplogroups trace migration?": "Haplogroups mark ancient lineages, revealing where ancestors lived and how populations migrated over thousands of years.",
 22  "What is the advantage of BigY for Globtrekker?": "BigY provides detailed SNP data for deep paternal ancestry and helps locate genetic cousins globally in the Globtrekker feature.",
 23  "What is the Y-DNA Haplogroup R1b?": "R1b is a common paternal haplogroup in Western Europe with many subclades, useful for tracing European ancestry.",
 24  "What is the Y-DNA Haplogroup J2?": "J2 is common in the Mediterranean and Caucasus regions, often linked to ancient agricultural populations.",
 25  "What is a founder effect?": "The founder effect occurs when a small population establishes itself, causing certain genetic traits to be more common.",
 26  "What is genetic drift?": "Genetic drift is the random change in allele frequencies in a population over time, affecting haplogroup distribution.",
 27  "What is admixture?": "Admixture is the mixing of genetic material from different populations, revealing multiple ancestral origins.",
 28  "What is a genetic match?": "A genetic match is someone sharing enough DNA to indicate a recent common ancestor.",
 29  "What is a Y-DNA STR marker?": "A Y-DNA STR marker is a short repeating DNA segment used to compare paternal lineage and calculate relatedness.",
 30  "What is a mtDNA H haplogroup?": "H is the most common maternal haplogroup in Europe, reflecting ancient migration patterns.",
 31  "What is a haplogroup tree?": "A haplogroup tree shows the branching patterns of human paternal or maternal lineages over thousands of years.",
 32  "What is a terminal SNP?": "A terminal SNP is the most recent SNP defining the end of a haplogroup branch.",
 33  "What is a deep ancestry test?": "A deep ancestry test uses BigY or full mtDNA to trace lineages thousands of years back in time.",
 34  "How can STRs estimate relatedness?": "STRs mutate relatively quickly, allowing estimation of how recently two individuals share a paternal or maternal ancestor.",
 35  "What is the difference between SNPs and STRs?": "SNPs are stable and define haplogroups, while STRs are variable and useful for estimating close relationships.",

 43  "What is the HaploTree?": "HaploTree is a phylogenetic tree showing relationships among Y-DNA or mtDNA haplogroups.",
 44  "What is a terminal branch?": "A terminal branch is the latest division in a haplogroup showing the most recent common SNP.",
 45  "What is a branch mutation?": "A branch mutation is a SNP that defines a new subclade in a haplogroup tree.",
 46  "What is a private STR mutation?": "A private STR mutation is a unique STR repeat change specific to a family line.",
 47  "What is a shared haplotype?": "A shared haplotype occurs when two or more individuals have the same set of genetic markers.",

 81  "What is autosomal DNA testing?": "Autosomal DNA testing examines chromosomes inherited from both parents. It can detect ancestry from all family lines within several generations. It is widely used for ethnicity estimates and finding relatives.",
 82  "Recommended tests for deep paternal ancestry": "For deep paternal ancestry, take a Y-DNA STR and SNP test (e.g., FamilyTreeDNA Y37 or BigY-700). For maternal, take full mtDNA sequencing. For basic tests, Family Finder is enough - gives autosomal DNA and Y-DNA SNP",
 83  "How accurate are autosomal tests?": "Autosomal test accuracy decreases for ancestry beyond ~7-8 generations. They are very good at detecting close relatives and continental ancestry, less precise for fine regional assignments far back in time.",
 84  "How to interpret regional match percentages on autosomal tests?": "Autosomal test companies use reference panels. A Circassian label does not exist; instead you'll see Northern Caucasus and neighbouring regions, i.e Southern Caucasus and Eastern Caucasus. In this context, Northern Caucasus is ~ Circassia. Interpret percentages as model-based estimates, not absolute identities.",

139  "How can DNA testing show Circassian ancestry?": "DNA testing can show genetic markers common in populations; however, linking to the Circassian identity specifically depends on the availability of reference samples and regional marker prevalence. Autosomal tests measure recent ancestry; Y-DNA / mtDNA trace single-line ancestry.",
140  "Which Y-DNA haplogroups are common among Circassians?": "Studies and public genetic data indicate Y-DNA haplogroups such as G2a2, J2, R1a, G2a1, J1, R1b, and also I2 and E are found among Northwest Caucasus populations at varying frequencies. Exact distributions vary by sample set and locality.",
141  "Why some Circassian-related results differ between test providers": "Different providers use different reference panels and algorithms; pass results through multiple methods and use raw-data-based third-party tools cautiously. The best is FamilyTreeDNA, it has Northern Caucasus, Southern Caucasus, and Eastern Caucasus clusters.",
142  "Can a single test confirm Circassian ethnicity?": "No - DNA can suggest regional ancestry and lineage markers, but ethnic identity also includes language, culture, and documented genealogy. Genetics alone rarely 'proves' a specific ethnic label.",
143  "Can mtDNA tests reveal maternal Circassian ancestry?": "Yes, mtDNA tests trace the maternal line. Common Circassian mtDNA haplogroups like H, U, W, K, T, and J may indicate regional ancestry. They provide deep maternal lineage information.",
144  "Should I use multiple tests for better results?": "Yes, combining autosomal, Y-DNA, and mtDNA tests gives a more complete picture. Each type provides different ancestry insights. Using multiple sources increases accuracy.",
145  "How to contribute Circassian reference samples for research": "Contact academic groups working on Caucasus genetics or established platforms (with ethical review) to contribute anonymized samples. Community projects or academic collaborations are ideal.",
146  "What is a founder effect in Circassian populations?": "Founder effects occur when a small population contributes disproportionately to later generations. Some Circassian clans show this due to historical isolation. It can increase frequency of certain haplogroups.",
147  "Can DNA reveal clan affiliations?": "DNA can suggest paternal or maternal lineage clusters. Some haplogroups may correlate with historic clans. Genetic evidence alone cannot fully confirm cultural or social affiliations.",
148  "How does FamilyTreeDNA protect my privacy?": "FamilyTreeDNA uses industry-standard security practices to store DNA samples, test results, and personal data, and allows users to control how their genetic information is shared.",
149  "Do they share my personal information with third parties?": "No, your name or other identifying information is not shared with third parties unless legally required or with your explicit consent.",
150  "How are DNA samples labeled and tracked?": "Each sample vial is labeled with a barcode linked to your order, scanned at check-in, and triggers a notification email to the kit owner.",
151  "Where is the DNA extracted and stored?": "DNA is extracted in a federally compliant CAP/CLIA certified lab and stored in a robotic freezer at -20ÃÂ°C for testing and future use.",
152  "How long is the second DNA vial stored?": "The second vial is stored at room temperature in a secured room for up to 25 years and used only if the first vial is insufficient.",

157  "What are the four bases in DNA?": "A, C, T, and G.",
158  "What are nucleotides?": "They are base pairs (AT or GC) that connect the two DNA strands like rungs on a ladder.",
159  "What are Short Tandem Repeats (STRs)?": "Sequences of identical nucleotides that repeat multiple times within the Y chromosome.",
160  "What is the value of an STR marker?": "The number of times the nucleotide sequence repeats.",
161  "What are multi-copy markers?": "STRs that occur in more than one location on the Y chromosome.",
162  "How are values of multi-copy markers reported?": "With hyphens, each number representing repeats in each location (e.g., 14-14).",
163  "What is an example of a multi-copy marker?": "DYS385, which is a repeat of GAAA occurring in at least two locations.",
164  "What is a palindrome in DNA?": "A hairpin-shaped structure where nucleotides pair with their mirror images, making the sequence the same forward and backward.",
165  "Why do some STR markers appear in multiple locations?": "Because they occur within palindromes on the Y chromosome.",
166  "How are STR repeats in palindromes reported?": "By counting repeats on each side, e.g., DYS385=14-14 or DYS385=13-14.",
167  "What is DYS464?": "A palindromic STR that often has four values, such as 15-15-17-17.",
168  "What is a marker change?": "A difference in the values of markers, regardless of order.",
169  "In the example of DYS464=15-15-15-16 vs 15-15-16-16, what is the GD?": "The GD is 1, because one marker copy differs.",
170  "In the example of DYS464=15-15-15-16 vs 15-15-16-15, what is the GD?": "The GD is 0, because the same values are present, just in a different order.",
171  "What is a copy change?": "A difference in the number of copies of a marker, regardless of their values.",
172  "How is GD calculated for copy changes?": "Any difference in copy number counts as GD=1, even if multiple copies differ.",
173  "In the example DYS464=15-15-15-16-16-16 vs 15-15-16-16, what is the GD?": "The GD is 1, since the extra copies likely arose in a single mutation event.",
174  "Why are multi-copy markers called fast mutating markers?": "Because they can change through both marker changes and copy changes, increasing mutation rate.",
175  "What should be considered when comparing GD in fast mutating markers?": "Their higher mutation rate, which can affect estimation of time to most recent common ancestor (TMRCA).",
176  "What do SNP names mean?": "Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs) are generally named after the lab or individual that first identified them. Each lab or individual is assigned a letter or series of letters, with the number following it representing the number of SNPs  they have identified. For example, FT1 was the first SNP identified by the FamilyTreeDNA BigY-700 test. FT2 was the second, and so on. Here is a complete list of all SNP name prefixes: https://help.familytreedna.com/hc/en-us/articles/9491505629967-SNP-Names",
177  "SNP names are?": "Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs) are generally named after the lab or individual that first identified them. Each lab or individual is assigned a letter or series of letters, with the number following it representing the number of SNPs  they have identified. For example, FT1 was the first SNP identified by the FamilyTreeDNA BigY-700 test. FT2 was the second, and so on. Here is a complete list of all SNP name prefixes: https://help.familytreedna.com/hc/en-us/articles/9491505629967-SNP-Names",
178  "What is Genetic Distance (GD) in Y-DNA testing?": "It measures the difference in STR markers between two individuals.",
179  "What is GD in Y-DNA testing?": "It measures the difference in STR markers between two individuals.",
180  "What is Genetic Distance?": "It measures the difference in STR markers between two individuals.",
181  "What is GD?": "It measures the difference in STR markers between two individuals.",
182  "How is GD sometimes described informally?": "As the number of -steps- between two STR values.",
183  "What does a GD of 0 represent?": "It means two people match exactly on the tested markers.",
184  "What does a GD of 1 indicate?": "There is a one-step mutation difference between two men.",
185  "What does a GD of 2 indicate?": "There is a two-step mutation difference between two men.",
186  "What does a GD of 3 indicate?": "There is a three-step mutation difference between two men.",
187  "What does a GD of 4 indicate?": "There is a four-step mutation difference between two men.",
188  "How is overall GD between two people calculated?": "By summing the GD values across all tested markers.",
189  "Why is GD important in genetic genealogy?": "It helps estimate whether two men share a common ancestor.",
190  "Can a higher GD suggest a more distant relationship?": "Yes, the larger the GD, the less likely a recent shared ancestor exists.",
191  "Does GD directly equal the number of generations back to a common ancestor?": "No, it only provides a probability, not an exact timeframe.",
192  "Which two main models are used to calculate GD?": "The Step-Wise Mutation Model and the Infinite Allele Model.",
193  "Why are two different models needed for GD?": "Because mutations can occur gradually or as structural changes.",
194  "What is the Step-Wise Mutation Model?": "A model where each single repeat change equals one step of GD.",
195  "How is a mutation counted in Step-Wise?": "Each increase or decrease of one repeat equals one unit of GD.",
196  "If one man has DYS19=15 and another DYS19=17, what is their GD?": "The GD is 2 steps.",
197  "Why is DYS19=15 vs DYS19=17 a two-step difference?": "Because the mutation would pass through 16 before reaching 17.",
198  "What GD is assigned if two markers differ by 3 repeats under Step-Wise?": "GD = 3.",
199  "Why is Step-Wise considered gradual?": "It reflects slow, single-step repeat mutations over generations.",
200  "Which type of STR mutations fit best with the Step-Wise model?": "Small, incremental repeat changes.",
Show lines 201-end
knowledgebase.json (rest)
  201  "Does Step-Wise consider large gaps as multiple steps?": "Yes, each repeat difference adds to the GD.",
  202  "What-s a -step- in GD terminology?": "One change in the number of STR repeats.",
  203  "Which model is used most often for single-copy STR markers?": "The Step-Wise Mutation Model.",
  204  "What is the Infinite Allele Model?": "A model where any difference between two values counts as GD=1.",
  205  "How does Infinite Allele treat a 10-repeat difference?": "It still counts as only one step.",
  206  "Why is Infinite Allele Model useful?": "It accounts for rare, structural, or large mutation changes.",
  207  "Which model ignores the size of the difference?": "The Infinite Allele Model.",
  208  "When is Infinite Allele preferred over Step-Wise?": "For null values or copy number changes.",
  209  "Why is Infinite Allele considered conservative?": "It avoids overestimating the number of mutations.",
  210  "If one man has DYS19=12 and another DYS19=20, what-s the GD under Infinite Allele?": "GD = 1.",
  211  "What is a drawback of Infinite Allele Model?": "It does not reflect the size of differences.",
  212  "Which model better captures single-step changes?": "The Step-Wise Mutation Model.",
  213  "Which model better explains one-off rare events?": "The Infinite Allele Model.",
  214  "What does a null value mean in Y-DNA STR testing?": "It indicates the marker is completely absent.",
  215  "How are null values usually represented?": "With the number 0.",
  216  "Why can-t Step-Wise handle null values correctly?": "It would count an unrealistic number of steps.",
  217  "If one man has DYS19=15 and another has DYS19=0, what-s the GD?": "GD = 1 under Infinite Allele Model.",
  218  "Why is GD=1 more accurate than GD=15 for null values?": "Because the loss of a marker is a single event, not multiple.",

  222  "Why are null values important in genealogy analysis?": "They can mislead calculations if treated incorrectly.",
  223  "How does Infinite Allele simplify null value interpretation?": "It reduces any null vs non-null difference to one step.",

  241  "Why is Step-Wise unsuitable for copy number changes?": "Because it would incorrectly count each missing copy as multiple steps.",

  496  "Why are purines paired with pyrimidines?": "Due to chemical bonding rules in DNA structure.",
  497  "What is the meaning of heteroplasmy in a test result?": "Presence of multiple nucleotides at one mtDNA position.",
  498  "What is the role of RSRS in modern testing?": "Standardizes ancestral mtDNA values for comparison.",
  499  "What is the role of rCRS in testing?": "Historical reference sequence used before RSRS.",
  500  "How do insertions differ from repeats?": "Insertions are new extra bases; repeats are duplication of existing sequence.",
  501  "How do deletions differ from extra mutations?": "Deletions remove base(s); extra mutations are additional changes not haplogroup-defining.",
  502  "Can transversions revert in later generations?": "Yes, such reversals are back mutations.",
  503  "Can transitions revert in later generations?": "Yes, also as back mutations.",
  504  "How is genetic distance calculated with heteroplasmy?": "Differences counted relative to ancestral or matching heteroplasmic values.",

  835  "What is Globtrekker on FamilyTreeDNA?": "Globtrekker is a feature that visualizes deep ancestral Y-DNA migration patterns worldwide, helping users trace ancient paternal lineages.",
  836  "How does Globtrekker work?": "It uses Y-DNA results to map haplogroup movements over thousands of years, showing where paternal ancestors likely lived and migrated.",
  837  "How does Globtrekker handle newly discovered SNPs?": "It updates haplogroup placement and migration paths as new SNPs are discovered and added to the Y-DNA tree.",
  838  "What is BigY-700 on FamilyTreeDNA?": "BigY-700 is a high-resolution Y-DNA test that analyzes hundreds of thousands of SNPs, providing detailed paternal lineage data.",
  839  "Why take BigY-700 to use Globtrekker?": "BigY-700 offers the most precise Y-DNA information, allowing Globtrekker to accurately place your paternal lineage in the global migration map.",
  840  "What are the advantages of using BigY-700 with Globtrekker?": "It increases the chance of discovering new branches, confirms haplogroup placement, and enhances the resolution of migration paths.",
  841  "Can Globtrekker be used without BigY-700?": "Yes, but with lower resolution; the more detailed BigY-700 data improves accuracy and the ability to explore deep ancestral connections.",

  843  "Can STRs improve Globtrekker results?": "Indirectly, STRs can support genealogical matching but do not define deep migrations like SNPs do.",

 5386  "Расскажи о древе Discover от FamilyTreeDNA": "Самое крупное Y-ДНК древо в мире! The World’s Largest Y-DNA Haplotree: https://blog.familytreedna.com/largest-y-dna-haplotree/. Количество образцов растёт быстрыми темпами, новые линии добавляются регулярно. Постоянное расширение делает FTDNA лидером по данным Y-ДНК.",
 5387  "Отличия FamilyTreeDNA из других лабораторий?": "26 лет на рынке услуг генетики и генеологии, пионер во многих аспектах, компания в 1B$. Своя лаборатория, не подряд в Китае и не аутсорс. Собственная база совпаденцев: Y-DNA, mtDNA, aDNA (аутосомы). Возможность создавать проекты как национальные, так и фамильные. Возможность выбора тестов, делать базовый Y37 (79-99$) или глубокий тест BigY700, публичная таблица. Собственные древа (включены в BigY700 и mtDNA Full), на котором образцов намного больше чем на древе YFull и разрыв усиливается (YFull требует 49$ за место на древе). Family Finder тест, всего за 39-49$ вы получаете аутосомные данные и ваш Y субклад (скоро добавят и мтДНК субклад, ждите обновлений). Возможность загрузки научных результатов, полных геномов WGS, ждём когда и от частников начнут принимать. Коллаборация с учёными, загрузка палеоДНК данных, даже таких, которые не может загрузить YFull. Американский бизнес — это когда рост доходов компании = вложения в развитие, в новые ДНК инструменты и сервисы. FTDNA предлагает надёжные, проверенные временем сервисы, полную поддержку и инновации в генетике. Компания обеспечивает максимальную прозрачность и доступность данных для пользователей.",
 5388  "Как FamilyTreeDNA использует древо Discover?": "Древо Discover отображает все Y-DNA линии, показывает новые ветви и миграционные маршруты, опираясь на тысячи образцов.",

 5391  "Что показывает функция Globetrekker?": "Globetrekker отображает географическое распределение ваших ближайших по отцовской линии родственников с помощью данных Y-ДНК.",

 5393  "Как Globtrekker помогает изучать древние миграции?": "Он использует результаты Y-ДНК для отображения перемещений гаплогрупп за тысячи лет, показывая, где жили и мигрировали предки по мужской линии.",
 5394  "Как Globtrekker обрабатывает новые SNP?": "При открытии новых SNP обновляется размещение гаплогрупп и пути миграции в дереве Y-ДНК.",

 5948  "Как используются результаты STR с базой данных?": "Для сравнения гаплотипов и выявления возможных родственников.",
 5949  "Что означают названия SNP?": "Однонуклеотидные полиморфизмы (SNP), или снипы, обычно называются в честь лаборатории или специалиста, впервые их определившего. Каждой лаборатории или специалисту присваивается буква или серия букв, а следующее за ней число обозначает количество идентифицированных SNP. Например, FT1 был первым SNP, идентифицированным тестом FamilyTreeDNA BigY-700. FT2 был вторым и так далее. Вот полный список всех префиксов названий SNP: https://help.familytreedna.com/hc/en-us/articles/9491505629967-SNP-Names",

Каждой лаборатории или специалисту присваивается буква или серия букв, а следующее за ней число обозначает количество идентифицированных SNP. Например, FT1 был первым SNP, идентифицированным тестом FamilyTreeDNA BigY-700. FT2 был вторым и так далее.
